newsitem.title: SLOVAKIA: Slovaks to launch 7.0 pct import surcharge - FinMin.
newsitem.headline: Slovaks to launch 7.0 pct import surcharge - FinMin.

text.p: Slovakia will impose a 7.0 percent import surcharge on all products except raw materials in the near future, the Finance Ministry said on Wednesday.

"The surcharge should become valid in the near future," Finance Ministry spokesman Jozef Mach told Reuters. "It has to be published in the official collection of laws, and we think it could become effective from August," Mach said.

The foreign trade deficit widened to 29.859 billion crowns for the January-May period of 1997, from 27.908 billion crowns in the first four months of the year. The country has been struggling with a growing current account deficit.
Slovakia abolished a widely-criticised import surcharge, imposed in 1994, at the beginning of this year, after cutting it to 7.5 percent from the original 10 percent in July 1996.
Mach said funds collected from the surcharge totalled 2.2 billion crowns in 1994, increasing to 3.3 billion the next year and rising to 3.8 billion in 1996.

In an attempt to curb the trade deficit, Bratislava introduced an unpopular import deposit measure last May, requiring importers to place an equivalent of 20 percent of their imports on an interest-free accounts for six months.
The Slovak government has said that the European Union had demanded the abolition of the import deposit measure arguing that it would rather accept an import surcharge.
The spokesman did not say if the government planned to abolish the deposit system when the surcharge comes into effect.
Slovakia was not named on Tuesday among the six countries scheduled to begin accession talks with the EU, but was listed as a potential candidate for future expansion.
